head.title: The Lives They Lived; What They Were Thinking

hedline.hl1: The Lives They Lived; What They Were Thinking

block.p: We were in a room, a spare studio, and Horst had this remarkable piece of furniture that he proceeded to drape me over every which way. He was very meticulous. He had a concept; it was my job to fit into it -- sort of like an actress with a director. He tells you how he sees it, and you find your way to doing it.

I don't recall that he had that great a sense of humor. I always goof around a bit to make myself feel more comfortable, but he wasn't playing. This was just work, serious work. He was more intent on his camera and lights than on making conversation.

He had a concept; it was my job to fit into it -- sort of like an actress with a director. He tells you how he sees it, and you find your way to doing it.

I don't recall that he had that great a sense of humor. I always goof around a bit to make myself feel more comfortable, but he wasn't playing. This was just work, serious work. He was more intent on his camera and lights than on making conversation.

He was getting on, already a bit of a legend, and I was very much conscious of the honor of being photographed by him. And so it was: ''Yes, Mr. Horst. Yes, Mr. Horst.'' Being there made me feel very young and inexperienced.

That was the thing with Horst: it was almost playing a role -- playing a movie star as opposed to shooting a picture of me. I suppose it was the way he treated me -- placing me and having the set already arranged. I remember feeling self-conscious in front of him, knowing that he had shot these huge female stars in the 40's and 50's. I felt I was pretending to be one of them.
This is his photograph, not mine; his idea of glamour and what a star should look like. I was an object in it.
